seg.seg: ... Thereupon he [i.e. the king] speaks: Say, [you] good ones, how shall I do? || In the Ś.-tune: || I [am] the ruler over the Jambudvīpa, the king, father by name (only)
... I make through my son. A word from him I ask, bowing with my body [and] with hands folded. But my wish is not fulfilled. Say [you],
Ein Wort von ihm erbitte ich, mich mit dem Körper beugend [und] mit zusammengelegten Händen. Aber er erfüllt meinen Wunsch nicht.
One word I ask of him, bending my body [and] with hands folded. But he does not fulfil my wish.
([you] noble ones, how shall I do? 1. Thereupon) the ministers say: There is a remedy for this. Pleased the king says: Of what kind is it? Thereupon
... (the ministers) say without ... to the king: Oh lord, there is no other thing here as much beloved as one's life. Therefore
There is no other thing as dear as one's own life.
... (the prince) will (only) be able ... to hide as (long) as he does not come into danger to [his] life. When he had heard that, the king Brahmadatta, without looking at his own son, (agreed).
Will he be able to hide himself as long as he does not come into danger of life? (cf 18)
... even called, in the presence (of a great crowd of people), the Caṇḍālas, who kill the ones to be killed, [and] says: Ho, deathsmen (?)! || In the S.-tune: || All over the world my

(command (?) is obeyed with reverence) [and] good will. Deliberately, however, this my son mocks the royal command [and] does not comply to say a single word, although [he is] able [to speak]. Seize him
Mit Absicht indessen verspottet dieser mein Sohn den königlichen Befehl [und] fügt sich nicht, ein Wort zu sagen, obwohl [er dazu] imstande [ist].
Deliberately this my son mocks a royal command [and] does not acquiesce to say a word, although [he is] able [to speak].
... If he does not say a word at all, take his life with the sword. 1. When he had heard that, the prince [began to] fear kingship even more.
If he does not say a word at all, take the life out of him with the sword! (cf 18)

... ([and] he thinks to himself: Oh, what) an awesomeness/cruelty that comes from the aberration of dominion of the kings! || In the W.-tune: || Because of masterly pride (the rulers) do (terrible things).
(But if) death becomes their master, then they go to the deep hells. The command to kill an impeccable son like myself [is]
(foolishness) ... [there?] is no longing for a royal sovereign/royal dominion. 1. When thereupon the Caṇḍālas knew the Bodhisattva [to be] surrendered by [his] father, the king,

... the naturally (cruel ones (?)), having tied the Bodhisattva’s flawless, tender arms to the back, as it were [= as if they were] without suffering, having placed the oleander wreath around his neck

p.note: The translation is largely based on 17-18, and .
259 suggests to translate ypamār ṣñi seyo rather as “I make ... of my son”, seyo being genitive rather than instrumental (133).
